title: Normal force vs time graph for block pulled upward

(15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is pulled by a rope that makes an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (theta) above the horizontal, as shown above. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and floor is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). frqParts.text: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) A block of mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is pulled by a rope that makes an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (theta) above the horizontal, as shown above. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and floor is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). The block is initially at rest and starts accelerating to the right along the floor. Three students each draw a diagram to indicate all of the forces that are exerted on the block as it moves. In the students’ diagrams, which are shown below, the lengths of the arrows indicate the relative magnitudes of the forces. Only one of the students has drawn a diagram that could correctly represent the forces. The other two students’ diagrams are incorrect. (a) Which student has drawn a diagram that could correctly represent the forces exerted on the block?

(b) For the incorrect student diagrams, explain why the diagram could not represent the forces exerted on the block. If there is more than one specific reason a diagram is incorrect, identify each of the reasons.

(c) Briefly explain why slightly increasing the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (without changing the magnitude of the force exerted by the rope) could cause a decrease in the block’s acceleration.

Suppose the rope is pulled with a force that has a magnitude that is one-third the weight of the block, or <math alttext="the fraction M g over 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. In this case, when the block accelerates, its acceleration is <math alttext="a equals g times, open parenthesis, one third of cosine theta, plus, the fraction mu over 3 times the sine of theta, minus mu, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.(d) Explain why the above equation is consistent with the claim that an increase in the angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> could cause a decrease in the acceleration.

The rope is now attached to the center of the top of the block, as shown above. The force exerted by the rope is initially zero newtons at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The force steadily increases, becomes equal to the block’s weight <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and continues to increase further. Three students sketch the graphs shown below to represent the normal force exerted by the floor on the block as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. One of the graphs is consistent with this scenario, while the other graphs are not consistent with this scenario. (e) Which graph is consistent with the scenario in which the force exerted by the rope on the block steadily increases?
(f) Identify all features of the other two graphs that make them inconsistent with this scenario. Explain your reasoning.

With one end of the rope still attached to the block, the other end of the rope is attached to a ceiling to create a pendulum with length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is much greater than the dimensions of the block. A second pendulum is made from an identical block and a rope of length <math alttext="L divided by 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. Both pendulums are displaced by the same small angle and released from rest. (g) Does the longer pendulum or the shorter pendulum have a greater period of oscillation? Briefly explain your choice without reference to equations, but by describing the restoring forces exerted on and motion of each block.
